questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after coughing up copious amounts of blood-tinged sputum at his nursing home. He has recently had an upper respiratory tract infection that was treated with antibiotics. He has a long-standing history of productive cough that has worsened since he had a stroke 3 years ago. He smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years until the stroke, after which he quit. The patient appears distressed and short of breath. His temperature is 38째C (100.4째F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Physical examination shows digital clubbing and cyanosis of the lips. Coarse crackles are heard throughout the lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows increased translucency and tram-track opacities in the right lower lung field. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with typical symptoms of bronchiectasis, including chronic cough with copious amounts of sputum, dyspnea, hemoptysis, and coarse crackles on auscultation. The exacerbation of symptoms following an acute respiratory tract infection, which this patient has, is also characteristic of bronchiectasis. The best initial test is a chest x-ray, which usually shows evidence of bronchial wall fibrosis (tram-track opacities), as seen here. The diagnosis of bronchiectasis is confirmed with a CT scan, which may further show honeycombing, bronchi dilation, and a signet-ring sign.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial section)

Numerous bilateral dilated bronchi (bronchiectasis) show wall thickening and an increased bronchoarterial ratio. Several bronchi imaged in cross-section have a diameter greater than the accompanying pulmonary artery diameter (1; signet ring sign), while others imaged in long axis have parallel walls (2; tram track sign).

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis is common in patients with a history of smoking and is characterized by a chronic, productive cough. However, copious amounts of blood-tinged sputum and signs of chronic hypoxia (e.g., digital clubbing, lip cyanosis) are less typical of chronic bronchitis. In addition, chest x-ray findings in chronic bronchitis are nonspecific. This patient's chest x-ray shows increased translucency and tram-track opacities in the right lower lung field, which are consistent with a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspiration pneumonia is a common complication in patients with a history of stroke, which may result in dysphagia. Patients with aspiration pneumonia may be asymptomatic or present acutely with dyspnea, cough, and hypoxemia, as seen here. However, chest x-ray in aspiration pneumonia typically shows pulmonary infiltrates in the lower lobes rather than the increased translucency and tram-track opacities seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of aspiration pneumonia

Heterogeneous consolidation is present in the lower lobe of the right lung (green circle). There is also fullness overlying the inferior aspect of the right hilum, which is suspicious for lymphadenopathy (red circle).

In an erect patient, aspiration is likely to involve basal lung segments as well as the middle lobe and lingula. The upper lobe posterior segments and lower lobe superior segments are more likely to be involved in a recumbent patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with emphysema usually present with a history of a chronic cough that is characteristically worse in the mornings, production of small amounts of sputum, and dyspnea. Since concomitant chronic bronchitis with a productive cough is common, the clinical presentation can be similar to this patient's symptoms. However, since the patient does not have signs of hyperinflation (e.g., a flattened diaphragm, wider intercostal spaces) on chest x-ray, which are typical for emphysema, the diagnosis is unlikely.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

Large lung volumes (green outline and arrows) are accompanied by intercostal space widening (examples indicated by red arrows) and diaphragmatic flattening, indicating hyperinflation.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism (PE) manifests with sudden onset of dyspnea, chest pain, coughing, tachycardia, and, in some cases, jugular venous distention. Hemoptysis, fever, and decreased oxygen saturation are also common, but this patient's history (cough, digital clubbing) suggests a chronic condition. While certain signs on chest x-ray should raise suspicion of PE (e.g., atelectasis, wedge-shaped opacities), these signs are not specific enough to establish the diagnosis, making them better suited to rule out other conditions. This patient's chest x-ray findings suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with pleuritic chest pain

A peripheral opacity (Hampton hump; green overlay) obscures the adjacent margin of the right hemidiaphragm. A Hampton hump is subpleural and is caused by pulmonary hemorrhage or infarction. The appearance is often wedge-shaped; however, it can alternatively be dome-shaped, if the apex is spared as a result of collateral bronchial arterial blood flow.

The differential diagnosis includes pneumonia and malignancy. Of note, the greater distance between the spinous processes and the medial edge of the clavicle on the right compared to the left indicates that the patient is rotated slightly to the right. The distances will be nearly equal when a patient is not rotated, whereas widening will be seen on the side to which a patient is rotated.

Dashed lines: margins of medial clavicles; White line and ellipses: spinous processes

F) INCORRECT:

Lung cancer is an important differential diagnosis in a patient with a history of smoking, chronic cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. However, while bacterial superinfections (e.g., pneumonia) are common and manifest with fever and a productive cough, the underlying chronic cough is typically mild and nonproductive. In addition, this patient's chest x-ray findings show no features of a lung tumor (e.g., solitary nodule, atelectasis, unilateral pleural effusion), making another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with bronchogenic carcinoma

A solitary nodule (red overlay) with an irregular margin is visible in the periphery of the upper left lung. An additional soft-tissue opacity peripheral to the nodule along the ribs may represent adjacent pleural thickening (green overlay).

The differential diagnosis for a solitary pulmonary nodule includes neoplastic (malignant and benign), inflammatory, and congenital conditions.
questions.hint: The most common congenital cause of this condition is cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 7-week history of cough, shortness of breath, and daily copious sputum production. He has had frequent respiratory tract infections over the past several years. Current medications include dextromethorphan and guaifenesin as needed. He does not smoke cigarettes. His temperature is 37.1째C (98.8째F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 133/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Diffuse crackles and wheezing are heard on auscultation throughout the lung fields. A CT scan of the chest is shown. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In bronchiectasis, damage to bronchial vessels is caused by transmural inflammation that leads to erosion and rupture of dilated bronchial wall vessels. Blood leaks into the conducting airways, usually resulting in mild, self-limiting hemoptysis, although severe hemorrhages that require embolization may occur. Additional CT scan findings of damaged bronchial vessels include dilated terminal bronchioles at the lung base, tram-track lines, honeycombing, and cystic changes.

B) INCORRECT:

Infection with Rhizopus spp. can cause mucormycosis, which is most commonly seen in individuals with an immunodeficiency syndrome, diabetes mellitus (especially diabetic ketoacidosis), and/or neutropenia. This patient has none of these conditions. While the mucociliary clearance defects in bronchiectasis increase the risk of fungal growth, the most common pathogens associated with this condition are Candida albicans and Aspergillus spp., not Rhizopus spp.

C) INCORRECT:

Rupture of pulmonary blebs commonly occurs in emphysema and leads to spontaneous pneumothorax. Risk factors for spontaneous pneumothorax include COPD with emphysema, interstitial pneumonitis, cystic fibrosis, and lung cancers. Although bronchiectasis can rarely lead to spontaneous pneumothorax, this patient's CT scan shows no signs of developing blebs.

D) INCORRECT:

Dysplasia of the pulmonary parenchyma is associated with the development of lung cancer. Risk factors include smoking, radon, arsenic, asbestos, and radiation. Bronchiectasis is not associated with an increased risk of lung cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Neoplastic growth of pleural cells leads to mesothelioma, which is most commonly associated with asbestos exposure. Bronchiectasis is not a risk factor for the development of mesothelioma.

F) INCORRECT:

Dysfunction of the left ventricle can cause congestive heart failure. Bronchiectasis can increase pulmonary vascular resistance, but this would lead to right heart failure due to dysfunction of the right ventricle (cor pulmonale) rather than left heart failure.
questions.hint: The features of a chronic cough with copious sputum production in a patient with recurrent respiratory tract infections indicate bronchiectasis. This diagnosis is confirmed by the CT scan of the chest that shows multiple dilated bronchioles as well as the signet ring sign.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after an episode of hemoptysis. He has a chronic cough that is productive of copious sputum. Six years ago, he had a stroke that left him with difficulty swallowing. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years, but quit 2 years ago. His respirations are 25/min and labored. Physical examination shows digital clubbing. An x-ray of the chest shows tram track opacities in the lower lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism (PE) can cause tachypnea, cough, and hemoptysis (due to pulmonary infarction). However, pulmonary embolism presents acutely with chest pain. Moreover, the findings suggestive of pulmonary embolism include regional hypovascularity, enlargement of the pulmonary artery, and in the case of pulmonary infarction, a wedge-shaped opacity and/or pleural effusion. This patient's history of a chronic cough, digital clubbing, and chest x-ray findings suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with pleuritic chest pain

A peripheral opacity (Hampton hump; green overlay) obscures the adjacent margin of the right hemidiaphragm. A Hampton hump is subpleural and is caused by pulmonary hemorrhage or infarction. The appearance is often wedge-shaped; however, it can alternatively be dome-shaped, if the apex is spared as a result of collateral bronchial arterial blood flow.

The differential diagnosis includes pneumonia and malignancy. Of note, the greater distance between the spinous processes and the medial edge of the clavicle on the right compared to the left indicates that the patient is rotated slightly to the right. The distances will be nearly equal when a patient is not rotated, whereas widening will be seen on the side to which a patient is rotated.

Dashed lines: margins of medial clavicles; White line and ellipses: spinous processes

B) INCORRECT:

Lung cancer is important to consider in a patient with a history of smoking, chronic cough, dyspnea, hemoptysis, and clubbing. However, this patient's x-ray shows no features consistent with this diagnosis (e.g., solitary nodule, atelectasis, unilateral pleural effusion).
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with bronchogenic carcinoma

A solitary nodule (red overlay) with an irregular margin is visible in the periphery of the upper left lung. An additional soft-tissue opacity peripheral to the nodule along the ribs may represent adjacent pleural thickening (green overlay).

The differential diagnosis for a solitary pulmonary nodule includes neoplastic (malignant and benign), inflammatory, and congenital conditions.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis is caused mainly by smoking and presents with a chronic, productive cough that is often worse in the mornings. It is not associated with digital clubbing or with tram track opacities on chest x-ray.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspiration pneumonia, which would cause tachypnea and a productive cough, is a common complication in patients with a history of stroke and subsequent impairments with swallowing. However, aspiration pneumonia would present acutely unlike the chronic symptoms in this patient and this patient's x-ray shows no findings suggesting aspiration pneumonia (e.g., infiltrates in the lower lobes).
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of aspiration pneumonia

Heterogeneous consolidation is present in the lower lobe of the right lung (green circle). There is also fullness overlying the inferior aspect of the right hilum, which is suspicious for lymphadenopathy (red circle).

In an erect patient, aspiration is likely to involve basal lung segments as well as the middle lobe and lingula. The upper lobe posterior segments and lower lobe superior segments are more likely to be involved in a recumbent patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Emphysema is caused by smoking and usually presents a chronic cough and dyspnea. However, since the patient does not have signs of hyperinflation (e.g., flattened diaphragm, wider intercostal spaces) on x-ray, the diagnosis is unlikely.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

Large lung volumes (green outline and arrows) are accompanied by intercostal space widening (examples indicated by red arrows) and diaphragmatic flattening, indicating hyperinflation.

F) CORRECT:

This patient presents with typical symptoms of bronchiectasis, including chronic cough, dyspnea, hemoptysis, copious sputum production, and clubbing. The exacerbation of symptoms by acute respiratory tract infections is also a common feature of this condition. Evidence of fibrosis of the bronchial walls (tram track lines) can be seen on chest x-ray. The diagnosis of bronchiectasis is confirmed with a CT scan. In addition to tram track lines and honeycombing, findings include dilated bronchi and, in some cases, a signet-ring appearance.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial section)

Numerous bilateral dilated bronchi (bronchiectasis) show wall thickening and an increased bronchoarterial ratio. Several bronchi imaged in cross-section have a diameter greater than the accompanying pulmonary artery diameter (1; signet ring sign), while others imaged in long axis have parallel walls (2; tram track sign).
questions.hint: Patients with Kartagener syndrome and other syndromes of ciliary dysfunction often develop this condition.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man reports 5 days of cough that produces blood-streaked yellow sputum, associated with intermittent fevers up to 39.2째C. He says that since age 32, he has been treated for pneumonia, on average, every 2 years.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The interferon-gamma release assay is a test for latent (asymptomatic) tuberculosis. It is not an appropriate test to further evaluate a symptomatic person with bronchiectasis.

B) CORRECT:

Recurrent pulmonary infections may result in bronchiectasis, with radiographic evidence of large lung volumes, tram lines, and variable opacities, as are seen in the chest radiograph. Recurrent infection may signal an underlying host-defense defect. Common variable immunodeficiency is most often detected in patients aged 20 to 40 years, often after considerable delay; it is treated with immunoglobulin replacement therapy. Hypogammaglobulinemia, which is more common in older patients, increases the risk for sinopulmonary infections, with corresponding damage to the bronchiole walls that results in radiograph-detectable dilation and destruction of the airway.

Key learning point: Recurrent pulmonary infections and radiographic findings of bronchiectasis in an older patient should raise suspicion for hypogammaglobulinemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody testing would be useful for suspected pulmonary vasculitis (microscopic polyangiitis or eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis), but the patients history does not suggest that.

D) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) levels are often elevated in sarcoidosis. Although bronchiectasis can be seen with sarcoidosis in rare instances, this case presentation is not typical for the disease. More importantly, ACE levels have limited utility in the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing in patients with bronchiectasis will often show obstructive disease with reduced FEV1 or evidence of air trapping, but these changes are nonspecific.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman presents with a cough that has been producing 4 to 5 tablespoons of purulent sputum daily for the past 3 weeks. It is associated with generalized fatigue and mild dyspnea on exertion. The patient has a history of recurrent sinusitis and, during the past 2 years, was treated as an outpatient for three separate episodes of community-acquired pneumonia.
On examination, the patient is afebrile and has a blood pressure of 136/87 mm Hg, a heart rate of 97 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 94% while she is breathing ambient air. She appears uncomfortable but is not in acute distress. Auscultation of the lungs detects bilateral scattered crackles and rhonchi. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rate and no gallops or murmurs, her jugular venous pressure is not elevated, and she has no rashes or clubbed digits.
Laboratory testing reveals normal leukocyte, hematocrit, creatinine, and serum electrolyte results. A chest radiograph does not reveal any cardiopulmonary abnormalities.
Which one of the following would be the best next diagnostic study for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Assessing for cystic fibrosis with a sweat test would be appropriate but not before first confirming bronchiectasis on CT scan.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated immunoglobulin E levels would suggest hyper immunoglobulin E syndrome (a rare cause of immunosuppression that can result in increased respiratory infections predisposing to bronchiectasis) but should not be ordered before a diagnosis of bronchiectasis is made.

C) CORRECT:

A chronic cough that produces a large volume of purulent sputum suggests the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. Although some patients have characteristic findings of bronchiectasis on chest radiograph (such as large lung volumes, tram lines, and variable opacities), the chest radiograph is less sensitive than high-resolution CT, the current diagnostic gold standard.

If high-resolution CT does establish a diagnosis of bronchiectasis, it is appropriate to conduct an evaluation for possible causes such as common variable immunodeficiency. (Quantitative immunoglobulin measurement is the best test for this disease.)

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to diagnose bronchiectasis is high-resolution CT.

D) INCORRECT:

Fiberoptic bronchoscopy can be used to look for airway obstruction if focal bronchiectasis is found on CT scan but is not used to establish a diagnosis of bronchiectasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis does not have a typical pattern on pulmonary function testing.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man with well-controlled type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia reports a one-year history of increasing cough with variable sputum production. Four times in the past 2 years, his primary care provider has treated him for episodes of bronchitis that were sometimes associated with weight loss.
The patient also reports frequent crampy abdominal pain with loose stools and intermittent sinus infections as an adult. He does not recall episodes of respiratory illness or pneumonia as a child. Married with no children, he is a recently retired schoolteacher and a lifelong nonsmoker.
His current vital signs are normal. Pulmonary examination reveals mid-lung-zone crackles and occasional wheezes. His FEV1 is 68% of predicted, his FVC is 80% of predicted, and his FEV1 /FVC ratio is 66% after bronchodilator use.
Recent high-resolution CT of the chest reveals middle- and lower-lung-zone-predominant bronchiectasis and mucous plugging.
Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear cytoplasmic antigen testing is used to assess for vasculitides such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegeners) or microscopic polyangiitis. Although bronchiectasis has been seen with both of these conditions (more commonly microscopic polyangiitis), it is a rare finding and not the most likely in this case.

B) CORRECT:

Bronchiectasis is often discovered radiographically in patients with unexplained, recurrent pulmonary infections and dyspnea. Plugging of medium-size airways results in dilation and damage to the airway that is distal to insult. Potential etiologies include large infection burden, impaired host defense, and chronic inflammatory states.

Of the choices listed, only immunoglobulin deficiency, diagnosed by measuring quantitative immunoglobulins, is implicated as a secondary cause of bronchiectasis that is unrelated to cystic fibrosis. Patients with immunoglobulin deficiency present with frequent infections and abdominal pain.

Key learning point: The most appropriate diagnostic test for identifying the cause of bronchiectasis in an older adult is quantitative immunoglobulin testing.

C) INCORRECT:

Galactomannan testing for aspergillosis is inappropriate because aspergillus infection is not a common cause of bronchiectasis. Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), an inflammatory, noninfectious response to aspergillus, can cause bronchiectasis. ABPA is not diagnosed by elevated galactomannan levels but instead by eosinophilia accompanied by elevated immunoglobulin E levels, as well as positive skin or serum testing for immune response to aspergillus.

D) INCORRECT:

Testing for endomysial antibodies for celiac sprue is inappropriate, as celiac disease is not associated with bronchiectasis.

E) INCORRECT:

A purified protein derivative skin test is appropriate for the workup of tuberculous lung disease but is not diagnostic for chronic, nontuberculous mycobacterial infection leading to bronchiectasis.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man reports a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath and cough that is productive of mucopurulent thick sputum. He has a history of bronchiectasis primarily affecting the right lower lobe that is attributed to a distant episode of necrotizing pneumonia. He has never smoked.
On examination, his temperature is 37.4째C, and his other vital signs are normal. Pulmonary examination reveals crackles and wheezes in the right lower lung field.
Laboratory evaluation is unremarkable. A chest radiograph demonstrates dilated and thickened bronchi in the right lower lobe without evidence of infiltrates.
Pending the availability of culture data, which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids are used to treat exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; they are not recommended in the treatment of acute or stable bronchiectasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin does not provide coverage against P. aeruginosa and is therefore not used for acute exacerbations. However, the medication's antiinflammatory properties can be used to prevent exacerbations.

C) INCORRECT:

Aerosolized recombinant DNase I is commonly used in cystic fibrosis as a mucolytic, but it has no benefit in, and might possibly harm, patients with bronchiectasis who do not have cystic fibrosis.

D) CORRECT:

Bronchiectasis, the permanent dilatation of bronchi, causes chronic cough and sputum production. It is associated with past severe pulmonary infections, congenital conditions such as cystic fibrosis and primary ciliary dyskinesia, and immunodeficiencies.

An acute exacerbation of bronchiectasis is characterized by worsening dyspnea and cough and an increase in sputum volume and purulence, without systemic symptoms. While the results of sputum culture are pending, empiric treatment consists of an oral antibiotic, such as a fluoroquinolone, that has complete or partial coverage for typical pathogens, including Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis, Staphylococcus aureus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. If the sputum culture grows Pseudomonas that is quinolone susceptible, the antibiotic should be switched to ciprofloxacin, which is a more narrow-spectrum antibiotic with better activity against P. aeruginosa. Of note, while the narrower spectrum of ciprofloxacin means that it is not a suitable agent for empiric treatment of respiratory infections (it lacks activity against many common respiratory pathogens), it nevertheless reaches therapeutic concentrations in the respiratory tract and is therefore suitable if infection with a sensitive organism has been confirmed.

Key learning point: While the results of a sputum culture are pending, the most appropriate treatment for an acute exacerbation of bronchiectasis is an oral antibiotic, such as a fluoroquinolone, that has complete or partial coverage for typical pathogens, including Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis, Staphylococcus aureus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

E) INCORRECT:

Results from studies of inhaled tobramycin for the treatment of acute exacerbations are mixed; routine use is currently not recommended.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of chronic cough productive of abundant purulent sputum. She also reports occasional hemoptysis and multiple exacerbations requiring antibiotics. She denies any occupational exposures. Physical examination reveals coarse crackles at the lung bases. A chest radiograph shows tram-track opacities.
Which of the following diagnostic modalities is most appropriate to confirm the suspected underlying pathology?

choices.text: High-resolution CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy allows direct airway visualization and is useful for obtaining cultures or biopsies. However, it does not adequately delineate diffuse structural changes like bronchial dilation, making it less suitable for confirming bronchiectasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function tests assess airway obstruction and lung function but do not provide anatomical detail. They cannot confirm structural airway abnormalities like bronchiectasis, which requires imaging to visualize bronchial architecture.

C) CORRECT:

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the chest is the preferred diagnostic modality for confirming bronchiectasis. It provides detailed images of bronchial dilatation, wall thickening, and lack of normal bronchial tapering, which are characteristic of this condition. HRCT can reveal the 'signet ring' sign, where the bronchus is larger than its accompanying pulmonary artery. This imaging technique accurately delineates the extent and distribution of structural lung abnormalities, essential for diagnosing bronchiectasis in patients with chronic productive cough, recurrent infections, and hemoptysis.

Key learning point: High-resolution CT (HRCT) of the chest is the gold standard for diagnosing bronchiectasis, providing detailed images of bronchial dilation and thickening.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial section)

Numerous bilateral dilated bronchi (bronchiectasis) show wall thickening and an increased bronchoarterial ratio. Several bronchi imaged in cross-section have a diameter greater than the accompanying pulmonary artery diameter (1; signet ring sign), while others imaged in long axis have parallel walls (2; tram track sign).

D) INCORRECT:

Sputum culture identifies bacterial pathogens during exacerbations but does not provide information about underlying anatomical changes. It is not useful for confirming structural abnormalities like bronchiectasis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents with increased shortness of breath and occasional hemoptysis. He has a five-year history of copious sputum production and reports frequent exacerbations managed with antibiotics. Current treatment includes inhaled bronchodilators and mucolytics. Examination reveals coarse crackles in both lung bases (see reports).

High-resolution CT scan: Dilated bronchi and thick mucus plugging in the lower lobes
Sputum culture: Grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Which intervention is most likely to improve symptomatic relief in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-term oxygen therapy is indicated for chronic respiratory conditions with resting hypoxemia. Bronchiectasis involves impaired mucus clearance, not primary oxygenation deficits. Oxygen therapy does not alter mucus viscosity or enhance clearance.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous corticosteroids are used for acute inflammatory conditions like severe asthma or COPD exacerbations. Bronchiectasis involves structural airway damage and chronic bacterial colonization, not acute inflammation. Corticosteroids do not enhance mucus clearance and may worsen bacterial colonization, as seen with Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

C) CORRECT:

Idiopathic bronchiectasis is characterized by permanent bronchial dilation, leading to impaired mucus clearance and chronic sputum production. This condition fosters bacterial colonization, such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, perpetuating airway inflammation and recurrent infections. Chest physiotherapy with postural drainage is essential in management, using gravity and manual techniques to mobilize secretions from peripheral airways. This method enhances mucus clearance, reduces bacterial load, and improves lung ventilation and functional status. By directing secretions toward the upper airways, it facilitates effective coughing, providing symptomatic relief and potentially reducing infection frequency.

Key learning point: In bronchiectasis, postural sputum drainage is an effective treatment option to improve airway clearance and reduce symptoms by facilitating mucus removal from the airways.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy is typically reserved for acute airway obstruction, unexplained hemoptysis, or diagnostic uncertainty, not routine mucus clearance in bronchiectasis. Its invasive nature poses risks like airway trauma and infection. Noninvasive techniques, such as chest physiotherapy and mucolytics, are preferred for chronic bronchiectasis management.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 7-week history of cough, shortness of breath, and daily copious sputum production. He reports frequent respiratory tract infections over the past several years. His current medications are dextromethorphan and guaifenesin as needed. He does not smoke. His temperature is 37.1째C, pulse is 88/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 133/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. On auscultation, diffuse crackles and wheezing are heard throughout the lung fields. A CT scan of the chest is provided. This patient is at greatest risk for which one of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection with Rhizopus spp. can cause mucormycosis, which is most commonly seen in individuals with an immunodeficiency syndrome, diabetes mellitus (especially diabetic ketoacidosis), and/or neutropenia. This patient has none of these conditions. While the mucociliary clearance defects in bronchiectasis increase the risk of fungal growth, the most common pathogens associated with this condition are Candida albicans and Aspergillus spp., not Rhizopus spp.

B) CORRECT:

In bronchiectasis, damage to bronchial vessels is caused by transmural inflammation that leads to erosion and rupture of dilated bronchial wall vessels. Blood leaks into the conducting airways, usually resulting in mild, self-limiting hemoptysis, although severe hemorrhages that require embolization may occur. Additional CT scan findings of damaged bronchial vessels include dilated terminal bronchioles at the lung base, tram-track lines, honeycombing, and cystic changes.

Key learning point: Bronchiectasis increases the risk of hemoptysis due to erosion and rupture of dilated bronchial wall vessels from chronic transmural inflammation.

C) INCORRECT:

Dysfunction of the left ventricle can cause congestive heart failure. Bronchiectasis can increase pulmonary vascular resistance, but this would lead to right heart failure due to dysfunction of the right ventricle (cor pulmonale) rather than left heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Rupture of pulmonary blebs commonly occurs in emphysema and leads to spontaneous pneumothorax. Risk factors for spontaneous pneumothorax include COPD with emphysema, interstitial pneumonitis, cystic fibrosis, and lung cancers. Although bronchiectasis can rarely lead to spontaneous pneumothorax, this patient's CT scan shows no signs of developing blebs.

E) INCORRECT:

Dysplasia of the pulmonary parenchyma is associated with the development of lung cancer. Risk factors include smoking, radon, arsenic, asbestos, and radiation. Bronchiectasis is not associated with an increased risk of lung cancer.
questions.hint: The features of a chronic cough with copious sputum production in a patient with recurrent respiratory tract infections indicate bronchiectasis. This diagnosis is confirmed by the CT scan of the chest that shows multiple dilated bronchioles as well as the signet ring sign.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with a persistent cough that has been present for several years. She reports producing nearly half a cup of thick, purulent sputum daily. Her history is significant for a severe pneumonia in childhood and at least five episodes of bronchitis requiring antibiotics in the last three years. She is a lifetime nonsmoker. On examination, her vital signs are normal. Auscultation of the lungs shows scattered crackles and rhonchi at the bases, which partially clear with coughing. A chest x-ray performed one year ago was reported as showing prominent bronchial markings. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: High-resolution computed tomography of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sputum culture is an important part of managing bronchiectasis, especially during exacerbations, because it helps guide antibiotic therapy by identifying colonizing or infecting organisms (e.g., Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Haemophilus influenzae). However, it does not establish the underlying structural diagnosis of permanent bronchial dilation. This test is for management, not for initial confirmation of the disease.

B) CORRECT:

The most appropriate study to confirm the diagnosis of bronchiectasis is a high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scan of the chest. HRCT is the gold standard because it can directly visualize characteristic findings, which include bronchial wall thickening, lack of airway tapering (tram tracking), and a bronchial diameter greater than that of the adjacent pulmonary artery (signet ring sign). Although a chest x-ray may be suggestive, it is often nonspecific or normal, making HRCT essential for a definitive diagnosis and for assessing the extent of the disease.

C) INCORRECT:

A sweat chloride test is used to diagnose cystic fibrosis (CF), which is a common cause of bronchiectasis, particularly in children and young adults. Although CF should be considered in the etiologic workup of bronchiectasis, this patient's age and history of a likely inciting event (severe childhood pneumonia) make non-CF bronchiectasis more probable. The immediate diagnostic step is to confirm bronchiectasis, not to test for a specific underlying cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) are often performed in the evaluation of patients with bronchiectasis to assess the degree of airflow limitation and monitor disease progression. The classic finding is an obstructive pattern (reduced FEV1/FVC ratio), similar to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. However, PFTs are not needed to establish the diagnosis of bronchiectasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy is an invasive procedure that is not used for the routine diagnosis of bronchiectasis. It may be indicated in specific situations, such as to evaluate for an airway obstruction (e.g., tumor, foreign body) as the cause of focal bronchiectasis or to obtain lower respiratory tract samples when sputum analysis is inconclusive. It is not the primary modality to confirm bronchiectasis.
questions.hint: This patient's history of chronic cough with copious purulent sputum, recurrent infections, and a prior severe lung injury suggests a diagnosis of bronchiectasis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with a history of non-cystic fibrosis bronchiectasis presents to the clinic with a 4-day history of worsening cough, increased sputum production, and dyspnea. Her sputum has changed from its baseline white color to thick and green. She has required three courses of antibiotics in the past year for similar episodes. Sputum cultures from a hospitalization 6 months ago grew Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Her temperature is 38.1째C (100.6째F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse crackles. Which of the following is the most appropriate oral antibiotic to initiate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin-clavulanate is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers common respiratory pathogens such as Haemophilus influenzae and Streptococcus pneumoniae, which can cause bronchiectasis exacerbations. However, it does not provide reliable coverage for Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Because this patient has a documented history of P. aeruginosa infection, this agent is inadequate.

B) CORRECT:

The most critical factor guiding empiric antibiotic therapy is her prior sputum culture growing Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Patients with bronchiectasis and a history of P. aeruginosa should receive empiric antipseudomonal coverage during exacerbations. Ciprofloxacin is an oral fluoroquinolone with reliable activity against P. aeruginosa and is a first-line option for outpatient management in this specific clinical scenario. Treatment is typically continued for 1014 days. A new sputum culture should also be obtained to guide future therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

While macrolides such as azithromycin are used in the long-term management of bronchiectasis to reduce the frequency of exacerbations due to their anti-inflammatory properties, they are not recommended as monotherapy for an acute, purulent exacerbation. Furthermore, azithromycin is not active against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, the likely pathogen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is a broad-spectrum antibiotic used for various respiratory infections, including those caused by atypical organisms. However, it is not active against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Therefore, it is not an appropriate choice for a patient with a known history of this organism causing prior infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole has a broad spectrum of activity but is not typically used for bronchiectasis exacerbations and, most importantly, does not provide reliable coverage against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Its use is generally reserved for infections caused by other specific organisms, such as Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, or for Pneumocystis jirovecii prophylaxis.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation of worsening cough, increased sputum volume, and purulence is suggestive of an acute exacerbation of bronchiectasis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with a history of non-cystic fibrosis bronchiectasis presents with a 5-day history of worsening cough, increased sputum production, and shortness of breath. Her sputum has changed from its usual white color to thick and green. A sputum culture from a similar exacerbation 6 months ago grew Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Her temperature is 38.1째C (100.6째F), pulse is 104/min, and respirations are 22/min. Oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Coarse crackles are heard at both lung bases. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial oral antibiotic therapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is a broad-spectrum antibiotic used for various respiratory infections, including those caused by atypical pathogens. However, it does not provide adequate coverage for Pseudomonas aeruginosa. In a patient with a high likelihood of pseudomonal infection based on past cultures, this would not be an appropriate empiric choice.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with an acute exacerbation of bronchiectasis, characterized by worsening cough, increased sputum volume and purulence, and dyspnea. The most critical factor guiding empiric antibiotic selection is her history of a prior sputum culture growing Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This history indicates a high risk for the current exacerbation being caused by the same organism. Ciprofloxacin is a respiratory fluoroquinolone with reliable oral anti-pseudomonal activity, making it the most appropriate initial choice. Treatment for exacerbations is typically continued for 1014 days, and therapy should be tailored based on results from a new sputum culture and sensitivity analysis.

C) INCORRECT:

While azithromycin is sometimes used as a long-term prophylactic agent in patients with bronchiectasis to reduce the frequency of exacerbations due to its anti-inflammatory properties, it is not recommended for the treatment of an acute exacerbation. It does not provide reliable bactericidal activity against common causative organisms, particularly Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin is a first-generation cephalosporin primarily used for skin and soft tissue infections caused by gram-positive organisms like Staphylococcus and Streptococcus. It has poor coverage against common gram-negative respiratory pathogens and no activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, making it an unsuitable choice for a lower respiratory tract infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin-clavulanate is a broad-spectrum antibiotic effective against common respiratory pathogens like Haemophilus influenzae and Streptococcus pneumoniae, which can cause bronchiectasis exacerbations. However, it does not provide reliable activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Because this patient has a history of a prior pseudomonal infection, empiric therapy must cover this likely pathogen.
questions.hint: This patient's history of a prior sputum culture growing Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most important factor in selecting an appropriate empiric oral antibiotic.
